bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 5, 1952

div1.p: Truby discusses who should be included - and who should be excluded - on the plaque to be placed at Camp Lazear. He thinks that Barstad and Mazzuri should be excluded.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 5, 1952

opener.dateline:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
November 5, 1952 Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.

div1.p:
I have your letter of October 28 and am sorry that illness
prevented me from sending you a reply sooner.

I concur in the conclusions of your letter and your action
concerning the program outlined by Pedro. The most astounding
thing to me was that they left out Lazear's important work at
Camp Columbia. Dean and Carroll, and also Dr. Pinto, certainly
belong on Pedro's list. Lazear's work at that time furnished
the real reason for the establishment of Camp Lazear for, in no
other way, could it be definitely proven whether the mosquito
was the carrier or not. Those experiments were just as important
as the later controlling experiments which were done at Camp
Lazear.

Pedro's remarks made about “the inoculations by Carroll and Reed
at Columbia Barracks with fresh, warm serum” were those done by
Carroll alone in Havana after Camp Lazear was closed. They had
no connection with thatthelatter Camp and could well be left out of Pedro's
program.

Pedro's list of persons to appear on the plaque I approve as you
have done. However, in order to make it clear, I think the list
of the men who took the fomite test (Cooke, England, Hildebrand)
and the men who took blood inoculations (Andrus, Forbes, and Olsen)
must be included.

I also feel that it is quite fitting to put Lambert's name on the
plaque as he did splendid work for Ames. The only thing about him
which I have criticized was his pernicious efforts to be placed
on the Roll of Honor to which the law did not entitle him. These
were my conclusions in my book, Pages 191-192.

I feel differently about Miss Warner for I am not competent to
state whether she is entitled to this honor or not. While writing
my book, my attention was called to her remarks in Kelly's book
on Yellow Fever. She stated, I think, that Walter Reed left the
Officer's Mess because of indecent remarks made by the younger
officers. You will find this explained on Page 198 of my book.
I think from information I obtained while investigating this
matter, that she was one of the nurses who cared for Lazear
during his illness. If so, I would favor placing her name on
Pedro's list. But I could not prove it. Kean felt as I do
about her remarks and I probably have his
statement in his file of letters

In regard to what you wrote me about John Peter Barstad, I have
no recollection about him at all. He may have been a member of
the Hospital Corps Detachment at Columbia Barracks, but he
certainly was not one of the volunteers. You know as well as
I do that the Board's final reports were complete in every
detail about the men who volunteered to take the tests. A
few years ago, someone sent me (and I remember you knew about
the case at the same time) information about Dr. Paul Mazzuri
who also claimed to have volunteered. He, likewise, could not
have done that without its being published in the Board's report.
I am enclosing the little card about Mazzuri for you to put in
your files. He belongs to your “pretender” list.

You might write to the Editor of the Minneapolis Tribune that if
they have any reliable information about Barstad's service in
Cuba you would like to have it so that the matter could be investi-
gated and tell them about what I said. I do not wish to rob a
dead veteran of any honors due him but there is something wrong
somewhere.

I feel highly honored to be included among those “who cooperated
too”. Whether or not I am entitled to such distinction, I don't
feel that I should comment. I think, however, that to that list
should be added Stark's name because he was of great help to
Reed in many ways and was just as enthusiastic, if not more so,
than anybody else at Camp Columbia.

I hope the “caseta” is still standing and as the season for hurricanes
is now about over for Cuba, it is probably safe for another year.
I am afraid Pedro is not going to be able to finish the plaque
properly with all of this haste and I should like to see the
ceremonies postponed for a few months.

After seven months in the Letterman Hospital following that fall of
mine in February, as I wrote you, I am back home and doing well
but still badly crippled. In other respects I am quite well. Give
my regards to Dr. Pedro Nogueira when you write him. He has been
most faithful in his efforts to help you.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Albert E. Truby
Brigadier General
U.S. Army, Retired Enclosure
